children.subject:
Leaving the answer box empty because I haven't actually done lc-style interviews yet, but I totally resonate with what you're saying and have been wondering the same thing all summer. I got a comfortable A+ in 61b with Hug (and in most of the other lower divs as well) and found that leetcode medium was much, much harder than anything I saw in his class. The very hardest algorithm / lab challenge questions he gave were leetcode medium-level roughly, except often we only had to give the general algorithm instead of implementing it fully.

I think the interview difficulty level comes down to a few things.

1) You can get a lot better at these questions with practice. I did close to 300 problems over the summer (I didn't have much else to do and I kinda enjoy leetcode lol), and I went from struggling a ton with mediums to being able to do new mediums in 20-30 mins and maybe half the hards in < 40. Once you learn the common "patterns" it gets a lot easier. You also get a lot better at coding the implementations. 

2) What I hear is that many, many interview questions are ripped straight from leetcode, and even if they're not they're probably similar to something you've seen. Given the amount of money these companies offer, it's created a "race to the bottom" where people do more and more leetcode, and so the interviews get harder and harder to differentiate. Some of the harder questions are just "well-known questions" that you should know. Median of two sorted arrays is one of these; it has nearly 5k upvotes on leetcode. Unless you're a straight genius, I don't think someone who's never seen this question would be able to code it up in 30ish mins, because although the concept isn't too too tricky it's a hard implementation.

3) I think internship interviews are much, much easier than full-time.

4) Maybe cal students get the benefit of the doubt on interviews? (There have to be a crazy number of false positives for these anyways given how common leetcode cramming is.) I've never heard this anywhere but it'd make sense imo.

history.content:
OP is referring to @9971. 

TL;DR communication skills are valuable and Leetcode mediums in a vacuum will not necessarily get you an internship.

Empirically I've noticed that companies have begun shifting away from asking Leetcode-style questions and instead focus more on good code quality and clarity of solution. For example, you may encounter a problem that is not that "puzzle"-y but requires substantial coding, and the interviewer is looking to see your thought process, how you break down the problem and choose to organize your code. I've personally found success in practicing for interviews by, well, doing interviews- it's most realistic when there's another person on the other side that you have to explain your thought process to clearly.

---

If you want to get an offer from every company you want, you just need to practice. If you feel that those medium questions are hard, do every single medium questions. It will take a long time, but there are no cutting corners here. If you can't solve a problem, think about it the next day. If you can't solve it after 2-3 days, then look at the solution, but generally, you should always get at least the naive solution without looking at solution.

Also, if you do enough problems, you will notice that there are patterns to many questions. For example, DP questions just require you to think what information you should save about the previous step, iteration. They all involve some sort of dp[][]... At least the easy ones. Array questions often involve little tricks like two-pointer trick, window trick, hashing trick, etc. Deque questions often involve saving values in consecutive settings. Hashmap questions often can be even further optimized by tuple tricks. Leetcode questions scratch the surface of the level of difficulty and is only there to introduce flavors of different questions. Try to think bigger picture when solving questions. Know your tools, your data structures, your tricks in your arsenal. Also, KNOW your languages. You should know cpp, java, python. Although python becomes useless in competitive settings. Be comfortable with all STL in cpp and all collections in Java. Leetcode questions are small-scale questions, like given one input, spit out output. Harder questions involve bigger inputs, and make you think more big picture with multiple queries. Analyze runtime in every approach before you start coding. You should never start coding before you analyze atleast two different approaches and their different runtimes. Since you mentioned a palindrome question, take a look at this one multiple query question: https://open.kattis.com/problems/palindromes

Study by topic, by data structures, by concepts. Also, have fun solving these problems! There is a thrill in seeing a question you don't know how to solve. Once you get to a point where a leetcode's hard problem is easy to you, then thats when you should feel comfortable knowing that you can get any offer you want. If you dont get to that level, there becomes a factor of luck in getting something. Good luck!

Hi all! As a sophomore,  I just started practicing Leetcode medium level questions, and I sometimes feel leetcode questions are even harder than the tests we take at Berkeley, and I may spend a long time just to come up with a solution to a question, sometimes even had to look up the answers...(for instance, the "median of two sorted array" and "Longest Palindromic Substring ") I am academically motivated and can do relatively well on classes and maintain a high GPA, however, the leetcode questions seem to require different mindset.. I'd like to sincerely ask for help from people with experience: how do you prepare for interviews? Are interview questions always this hard? I saw from one of the poll on EECS 101 piazza that many people didn't even practice many leetcode questions and successfully land on an internship, and Berkeley students normally can successfully find a good CS job before graduation. Does this mean the interview questions are normally not that bad? 

 I really appreciate any advice and help!
history.subject: Feeling leetcode questions difficult?
